Availability of IBM Java from the Canonical Partner archive.

First of all the Partner archive needs to be enabled first: 

Before doing that you may want to backup your sources.list file:

<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ ls -lad /etc/apt/sources.list* </code>
<code>-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 3353 Mar 24 06:36 /etc/apt/sources.list </code>
<code>drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Mar 24 06:35 /etc/apt/sources.list.d </code>
<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ sudo cp /etc/apt/sources.list /etc/apt/sources.list_`date +%Y%m%d`.backup </code>
<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ ls -lad /etc/apt/sources.list*-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 3383 Mar 24 06:36 /etc/apt/sources.list </code>
<code>-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 3353 Apr  6 09:55 /etc/apt/sources.list_20170508.backup </code>
<code>drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Mar 24 06:35 /etc/apt/sources.list.d </code>

Now edit your /etc/apt/sources.list manually or just execute:

<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ sudo add-apt-repository "deb http://archive.canonical.com/ubuntu $(lsb_release -sc) partner" </code>

You should no have some entries like this in your sources.list file:

<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ grep ^deb.*partner /etc/apt/sources.list </code>
<code>deb http://archive.canonical.com/ubuntu xenial partner </code>

If so just update the archive indices with:

<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ sudo apt update -qq </code>

You should now be able to find the packages with:

<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ apt list | grep ^ibm </code>
<code> </code>
<code>WARNING: apt does not have a stable CLI interface. Use with caution in scripts. </code>
<code> </code>
<code>ibm-java80-jdk/xenial 8.0.4.1-0ubuntu1 ppc64el </code>
<code>ibm-java80-jre/xenial 8.0.4.1-0ubuntu1 ppc64el </code>

Or just have a direct look in the package archive files:

<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ grep Package /var/lib/apt/lists/archive.canonical.com_ubuntu_dists_$(lsb_release -sc)_partner_binary-ppc64el_Packages | grep ibm-java </code>
<code>Package: ibm-java80-jdk </code>
<code>Package: ibm-java80-jre </code>

Get more details about the installation candidates with:

<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ apt-cache policy ibm-java80-jdk ibm-java80-jre </code>
<code>ibm-java80-jdk: </code>
<code>  Installed: (none) </code>
<code>  Candidate: 8.0.4.1-0ubuntu1 </code>
<code>  Version table: </code>
<code>     8.0.4.1-0ubuntu1 500 </code>
<code>        500 http://archive.canonical.com/ubuntu xenial/partner ppc64el Packages </code>
<code>ibm-java80-jre: </code>
<code>  Installed: (none) </code>
<code>  Candidate: 8.0.4.1-0ubuntu1 </code>
<code>  Version table: </code>
<code>     8.0.4.1-0ubuntu1 500 </code>
<code>        500 http://archive.canonical.com/ubuntu xenial/partner ppc64el Packages </code>

Finally let's do a quick verification and let's close we the almost mandatory  HelloWorld example:

<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ vi HelloWorld.java </code>
<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ cat HelloWorld.java </code>
<code>public class HelloWorld { </code>
<code> </code>
<code>    public static void main(String[] args) { </code>
<code>        System.out.println("Hello "+System.getProperty("os.arch")+" World!"); </code>
<code>    } </code>
<code> } </code>
<code>ubuntu@ppc64el:~$ javac HelloWorld.java </code>
